title: Free Energy Principle Overview
description: Introduction to the Free Energy Principle as a unifying theory of brain function, perception, and action.
learning_objectives: State the Free Energy Principle mathematically
Understand free energy as prediction error
Connect FEP to information theory and Bayesian inference
Explain how FEP unifies perception and action

content.overview: The Free Energy Principle (FEP) is a theoretical framework that explains how biological systems maintain their integrity by minimizing a quantity called 'free energy'. It provides a unifying account of brain function, perception, learning, and behavior.

core_principle.statement: All biological systems minimize their free energy to maintain their structural and functional integrity.
core_principle.interpretation: Free energy decreases over time (or stays constant in equilibrium)

variational_formulation.free_energy_definition: F[q] = E_q[log q(θ) - log p(x,θ)] = D_KL[q(θ)||p(θ|x)] - log p(x)
variational_formulation.surprise_bound: Free energy F ≥ -log p(x) provides upper bound on surprise
variational_formulation.evidence_lower_bound: ELBO = -F provides lower bound on log evidence

biological_interpretation.survival_imperative: Systems that minimize free energy are more likely to survive
biological_interpretation.self_organization: Free energy minimization drives emergence of structure
biological_interpretation.adaptive_behavior: Behavior that reduces free energy is selected
biological_interpretation.predictive_brain: Brain as prediction machine minimizing surprise

mathematical_derivation.starting_point: p(x) = ∫ p(x|θ) p(θ) dθ - marginal likelihood
mathematical_derivation.jensen_inequality: log p(x) = log E_q[p(x|θ) p(θ)/q(θ)] ≤ E_q[log p(x|θ) p(θ)/q(θ)]
mathematical_derivation.free_energy_bound: F[q] = E_q[log q(θ) - log p(x,θ)] ≥ -log p(x)

free_energy_definition.prediction_error: Free energy bounds surprise: F ≥ -log p(x)
free_energy_definition.interpretation: Free energy is an upper bound on surprise (negative log likelihood)

key_components.name: Generative Models
key_components.description: Internal models that predict sensory inputs

key_components.name: Variational Density
key_components.description: Approximate posterior distribution over model parameters
key_components.role: Represents current beliefs about the world

perception_as_inference.principle: Perception is the process of inferring the causes of sensory input
perception_as_inference.mechanism: Update internal model to minimize free energy

action_as_inference.principle: Action is the process of selecting actions to fulfill predictions
action_as_inference.mechanism: Select actions that minimize expected free energy
action_as_inference.outcome: Actions change the world to match predictions

biological_implications.description: Brain minimizes free energy through hierarchical predictive coding
Natural selection favors free energy minimizing organisms
Phenomenal experience arises from free energy minimization

mathematical_connections.information_theory: Free energy bounds surprise and information gain
mathematical_connections.bayesian_inference: Free energy minimization implements Bayesian updating
mathematical_connections.variational_methods: FEP uses variational approximation for inference

information_theory.surprise_minimization: Free energy bounds surprise: F ≥ -log p(x)
information_theory.information_gain: Reducing free energy increases model evidence
information_theory.entropy_regularization: KL divergence term acts as entropy regularization
information_theory.predictive_information: Mutual information I(θ;x) bounds free energy reduction

bayesian_inference.variational_bayes: Free energy minimization implements variational Bayesian inference
bayesian_inference.evidence_maximization: Minimizing F maximizes model evidence p(x)
bayesian_inference.belief_updating: Gradient descent on F implements Bayesian updating

statistical_physics.thermodynamic_analogy: Variational free energy analogous to thermodynamic free energy
statistical_physics.equilibrium: Minimum free energy corresponds to equilibrium state
statistical_physics.phase_transitions: Free energy landscape can have multiple minima
statistical_physics.self_organization: Free energy minimization drives pattern formation

control_theory.optimal_control: Active inference as optimal control with uncertainty
control_theory.homeostatic_control: Maintain internal states through active regulation
control_theory.adaptive_control: Learn control policies through free energy minimization

examples.name: Visual Perception
examples.description: Brain predicts visual input and updates beliefs based on errors
examples.process: Retinal signals → prediction errors → belief updating → refined predictions

mathematical_model.generative_model: p(x|θ) where x are visual features, θ are object properties
mathematical_model.updating: dθ/dt = -∂F/∂θ - gradient descent on free energy
mathematical_model.perception: θ* = argmin_θ F(θ|x) - best explanation of visual input

neurobiological_interpretation.hierarchical: Multiple levels of prediction and error correction

examples.name: Motor Control
examples.description: Motor commands selected to minimize predicted proprioceptive errors
examples.process: Intended movement → predicted sensations → action → error correction

mathematical_model.expected_cost: G(π) = E[F(π)] - expected free energy of policy
mathematical_model.optimal_policy: π* = argmin_π G(π) - minimize expected free energy

neurobiological_interpretation.efference_copy: Copy of motor command to predict sensory consequences
neurobiological_interpretation.forward_models: Internal models of body and environment dynamics
neurobiological_interpretation.error_correction: Adjust movements to reduce prediction errors

examples.name: Homeostatic Regulation
examples.description: Body maintains temperature by minimizing physiological prediction errors
examples.process: Set point → prediction → deviation → corrective action

mathematical_model.prediction_error: ε = θ - θ* - deviation from setpoint
mathematical_model.free_energy: F = (1/2)ε² + (λ/2)u² - balance regulation vs control cost

physiological_interpretation.allostasis: Anticipatory regulation to meet future demands

examples.name: Social Interaction
examples.description: Predict and respond to others' behavior in social contexts
examples.process: Observe others → predict behavior → interact → update social model

mathematical_model.social_generative_model: p(o, s|θ) where o are observed actions, s are hidden intentions
mathematical_model.joint_attention: Predict where others will look or what they will do

psychological_interpretation.mirror_neurons: Predict others' actions through motor simulation

levels_of_processing.sensory_level: Raw sensory input and immediate responses

prediction_hierarchy.contextual_modulation: Higher levels provide context for lower levels
prediction_hierarchy.precision_weighting: Attention modulates precision of prediction errors

interactive_exercises.description: Interactive simulation of free energy minimization in simple generative models
steps: Design a simple generative model p(x|θ) for a known distribution
Implement variational inference to approximate the posterior q(θ|x)
Compute free energy F[q] and track its minimization
Compare with exact Bayesian inference when possible
Analyze how different priors affect the results
interactive_exercises.validation: Verify that F ≥ -log p(x) and that equality holds for optimal q

interactive_exercises.description: Calculate prediction errors and free energy for various generative models
steps: Set up a generative model with known parameters
Generate synthetic observations from the model
Implement variational inference to estimate parameters
Calculate prediction errors and free energy
Analyze how model complexity affects free energy
interactive_exercises.validation: Compare variational results with exact inference

interactive_exercises.description: Implement a simple perception-action loop using free energy minimization
steps: Design an agent with a generative model of its environment
Implement perception: infer hidden states from observations
Implement action: select policies that minimize expected free energy
Create a simple environment for the agent to interact with
Analyze how the agent learns and adapts over time
interactive_exercises.tools: Python, reinforcement learning frameworks, Active Inference implementations
interactive_exercises.validation: Compare agent performance with standard RL algorithms

interactive_exercises.description: Analyze hierarchical prediction and error propagation in multi-level models
steps: Design a hierarchical generative model with multiple levels
Implement prediction flow from top to bottom levels
Implement error propagation from bottom to top levels
Analyze how context from higher levels affects lower level predictions
Study how attention modulates prediction precision
interactive_exercises.validation: Test predictions against empirical data from neuroscience

unified_theory.brain_as_inference_machine: Brain as Bayesian inference engine minimizing surprise
unified_theory.perception_action_unity: Perception and action as two sides of the same coin
unified_theory.self_organization: Structure emerges from free energy minimization
unified_theory.consciousness: Phenomenal experience as free energy minimization

scientific_unification.thermodynamics: Connection between information and thermodynamic entropy
scientific_unification.evolution: Natural selection as free energy minimization
scientific_unification.learning_theory: All learning as free energy minimization

implications_for_ai.artificial_general_intelligence: Path to AGI through free energy minimization

common_misconceptions.misconception: Free energy is the same as thermodynamic free energy
common_misconceptions.clarification: Variational free energy is information-theoretic, not thermodynamic

common_misconceptions.misconception: FEP only applies to brain function
common_misconceptions.clarification: FEP applies to all biological self-organization
FEP operates at all levels, from cells to conscious brains

further_reading.title: The Free Energy Principle: A Rough Guide to the Brain?
further_reading.author: Karl Friston
further_reading.description: Seminal paper introducing the Free Energy Principle
further_reading.key_contribution: First comprehensive statement of the FEP

further_reading.title: A Free Energy Principle for Biological Systems
further_reading.author: Karl Friston
further_reading.key_contribution: Extended FEP to all biological systems

further_reading.title: Active Inference: The Free Energy Principle in Mind, Brain, and Behavior
further_reading.author: Thomas Parr, Giovanni Pezzulo, Karl Friston

further_reading.title: The Mathematical Foundations of the Free Energy Principle
further_reading.author: Community literature
further_reading.key_contribution: Current research directions and theoretical extensions

variational_methods.mean_field_approximation: Simple but potentially inaccurate for complex posteriors
variational_methods.sampling_methods: MCMC for exact inference when feasible

numerical_stability.log_probabilities: Work in log space to avoid numerical underflow
numerical_stability.gradient_clipping: Clip gradients to prevent exploding gradients

computational_efficiency.online_learning: Update beliefs incrementally as new data arrives
computational_efficiency.memory_optimization: Optimize memory usage for large models

metadata.author: Active Inference Community
metadata.enhancement_notes: Enhanced with comprehensive mathematical formulations, detailed examples, hierarchical structure, philosophical implications, implementation considerations, and extensive interactive exercises
